name: Sophie Foster-Canfield
comment info:
"How does your diet compare to this families diet?"

I notice that protein is the most expensive section but that whole fruit (located in the fruit section) is the most expensive item. The fruit section is actually the second cheapest even though it contains the most expensive item. The vegetables section and the protein section are tied for most amount of items. Both have five items and they are only $1 apart in cost. Dairy has three items while grains has four items. Grains is $3 more than dairy. I wonder if the closer the amount of items are the closer the price is. 
I also notice that the healthier the food the more it costs. For example candy only costs $8 while fruit is $19. 
Another thing I see is that this families diet is different from mine. I rarely get candy or anything else junk foodie like cereal, and I'm a vegetarian. I wonder if that lowers my families weekly food cost (I live in a family of four unless you count my 8 chickens and 2 cats).

name: Amelia Prindle
comment info:
Title: Food for A Family of Four

What I notice is that this graph shows a family of four's weekly food plan, showing the different products purchased. They spend the most on protein ($47), followed by vegetables ($46), then grains ($31), dairy ($28), fruit ($27), and lastly other ($14). The graph shows the different categories of foods as well as subcategories such as dark green vegetables, or seafood. Thinking about how a "normal" diet is they seem to be buying balanced meals, and the amount of processed food is limited. I also notice that the bill seems very low compared to what I have seen especially for a family of four. I wonder how old the children in the families are and if they eat more at home or eat out too. Another thing I wonder is if they were purchasing name grocery store brand products (such as Market Basket or Shaw's) or if they are buying organic which likely would greatly increase the spending amount. The last thing I wonder is that if they were to purchase more processed foods if the weekly budget would increase or decrease.

name: Maria Fernanda Correa
comment info:
This graph from the Department of Agriculture sets out a suggested distribution of a staple budget. They attempt to include a 'balanced' food model for an average family of 4 people for a total of $193 per week. At first sight, it seems like a massive help for many families who benefit from this resource.

On the other hand, They suggest a diet based on animal protein, which is the highest budget, $47, regardless of how harmful the number of antibiotics, hormones, and steroids added can be for daily consumption.

Nevertheless, many scientific studies have shown that the daily consumption of animal meats is directly related to cancerous diseases. Still, unfortunately, some government institutions & health organizations continue to refer people to these types of diets.

After analyzing the "Thrifty Food Plan," there is a question: is the government interested in the people's health, or is it simply looking to benefit private companies and fulfill just one more item on its agenda?

I am convinced that the government should have an essential role in educating citizens. Therefore, it is not enough to give them the money. They have to provide them the tools to make informed decisions that impact their well-being and their families. Otherwise, it would be hard to decrease the number of heart disease deaths, overweight, and diabetes.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's line moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows the Department of Agriculture’s newly revised Thrifty Food Plan, the food groups used to estimate the cost of an economical, nutritious diet.   This plan is the basis of the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP).   Note the allocation to food groups is the basis of calculating the SNAP benefits.  Recipients can spend their benefits as they choose.  Although the payments may seem modest for middle-income Americans, the program reduces hunger, improves nutrition and lead to better health.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions plus, a catchy headline that captures the ideas in this graph. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, Oct. 15 with moderation on Wednesday, Oct. 20.  The topic:  Pandemic Inflation.  Keep noticing and wondering.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info:
HI, @Kaiden comet --

You are right that food costs vary depending on where you shop.  The SNAP benefits are uniform nationally by income level and family size, except for Alaska and Hawaii.  States can supplement the benefit.  You can search online for the per person SNAP benefit in Michigan, as well as other SNAP statistics.

name: Maggie M AOSE
comment info:
What do you notice? 
This graph shows the weekly cost an average family of four spends on food. This average comes to $193, with $47 being spent on protein and $46 spent on vegetables. The price of these two contribute too close to half of the total cost. 

What do I wonder?
As I previously mentioned, protein and vegetables contribute to about half the amount of cost spent by families on food weekly. I wonder is this due to families having more of a need for protein and vegetables or is it more closely related to the cost of the products?

How does this relate to you or your community?
My parents go out weekly and buy the groceries for the week and likely have a budget similar to the one in this graph. Seeing each meal is close to $7 it makes me feel more grateful with what my parents are able to give me.

"Food for Thought"

name: Corey Francis
comment info: Anything released by the government is going to be criticized and this is not an exception. Firstly the dairy section is huge, who is the dairy demon guzzling this much yogurt? And a system that 1 in 8 Americans use seems like a great avenue to cut down on the amount of meat we eat but it's not being taken advantage of. This much money seems applicable for 4 adults but not children which make up 43% of the people that rely on SNAP. Remember that these kids are also eating at school and it starts to look like a big excess.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Corey Francis --

You bring up a good point – why do much diary and meat?  There is information online about how the market basket was selected.  Recipients do get to spend their benefits as thy choose from a long list of food options.  Spending less on meat would free up a lot for other foods.

How about a headline?

name: Laura's Last Ditch
comment info: The beans, peas, and lentils can be enlarged, go over into the protein category, and the meat could be significantly reduced. Change it to dried beans and fund an Instant Pot for each family to make cooking the beans quick and easy. While an Instant Pot wouldn't do for someone living without electricity, it would work with most, even people who are living in a hotel room. Honestly, I think $193 seems like a lot of money to spend on food for one week--if a person has access to an actual grocery store.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info:
@Laura's Last Ditch That $193 is for 4 people, so that would be about $48 per person per week. 

I think you last comment is the most important. All of this assumes that everyone has easy and convenient access to a grocery store, which is often not the case.
